content:
Introduction

Fetal development is the process by which a fertilized egg grows into a viable fetus; this process spans approximately 38 weeks from the date of fertilization.  By convention, pregnancy dating in a clinical setting is usually referred to in terms of gestational age (time since the first day of the last menstrual period).  In contrast, the fertilization or embryonic age (time since fertilization occurred) is used to discuss the early events in embryonic development.  In patients with regular 28-day menstrual cycles, the embryonic age is approximately 2 weeks less than the gestational age.



Fetal development is divided into 3 main stages:



  • Preembryonic stage:  0-2 weeks after fertilization.
  • Embryonic stage:  2-8 weeks after fertilization.
  • Fetal stage:  >8 weeks after fertilization (or >10 weeks gestation) to birth.


Each stage involves critical milestones, growth, and structural transformations that are influenced by genetic, hormonal, and environmental factors (

figure 1
).

Preembryonic stage (0-2 weeks after fertilization)

Key events



  • Fertilization (
    figure 2
    ):  Fertilization occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.  The sperm penetrates the zona pellucida of the ovum, allowing its genetic material to enter, forming a zygote.  The zygote is swept through the fallopian tube toward the uterus by ciliary action and peristalsis of the muscularis mucosa.
  • Cleavage:  The zygote undergoes a series of mitotic divisions, becoming a blastula and eventually reaching the 16- to 32-cell morula stage (
    figure 3
    ).  The morula enters the uterus on day 4 and is composed of an inner and outer cell mass, which become the embryo and placenta, respectively.
  • Blastulation:  With the formation of a fluid-filled cavity (blastocoel), the morula becomes a blastocyst (
    figure 3
    ).  The inner cell mass of the blastocyst becomes the embryoblast, and the outer cell mass becomes the trophoblast.
  • Implantation:  The blastocyst implants into the uterine wall on day 6 or 7 (
    figure 5
    ).
  • Differentiation:  The trophoblast and embryoblast further differentiate:
    • The trophoblast develops into the cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast (which produces Î²-hCG detectable in maternal blood as early as day 8)
      figure 6
      ).  The syncytiotrophoblast grows into the endometrium and establishes a connection with the maternal vasculature, forming the basis of the future uteroplacental circulation.
    • The embryoblast differentiates into 2 layers, forming the bilaminar embryonic disk (
      figure 7
      ).  The dorsal layer (epiblast) contributes to the amniotic cavity.  The ventral layer (hypoblast) contributes to the yolk sac (
      figure 8
      ).

Clinical considerations



  • Ectopic pregnancy (
    figure 9
    ):  Delayed transport through the fallopian tube can lead to the implantation of the blastocyst in the fallopian tube or other locations outside the uterus.
  • Monozygotic twin gestation (
    figure 10
    ):  Monozygotic gestation results from the splitting of the embryoblast on days 8-12; conjoined twins result from incomplete splitting at â‰¥day 13.
  • Teratogens typically do not affect development during this period due to the "all-or-none" principle (ie, the pregnancy either fails or continues to develop and is unaffected by the exposure).

Embryonic stage (2-8 weeks after fertilization)



The embryonic stage is the most critical period of development because the basic body plan and all major organ systems begin to formâ€”a process called organogenesis.  The homeobox (Hox) genes are responsible for establishing craniocaudal orientation (

figure 11
).  The sonic hedgehog (SHH) and WNT genes are involved in patterning in the dorsal-ventral axis and organ development.

Week 3 key events



  • Gastrulation (cellular migration and differentiation to form the 3 germ layers:  ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) (
    figure 12
    ):  Begins with the formation of the primitive streak within the epiblast, establishing the anteroposterior axis of the embryo.  The ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm develop into different body tissues later in development (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ).
  • Neurulation (formation of the neural tube):  Begins with the formation of the neural plate in the ectoderm layer (
    figure 13
    ).  Formation of the neural tube (precursor to the brain and spinal cord) occurs as the lateral edges of the neural plate (neural folds) migrate toward the midline.
  • The primitive heart tube forms (
    figure 14
    ).
  • Folding of the dorsal aspect of the yolk sac into the embryo results in the formation of the primitive gut tube (composed of the foregut, midgut, and hindgut).

Week 4 key events



  • The neural tube closes, and the primary brain vesicles (prosencephalon, mesencephalon, rhombencephalon) form (
    figure 15
    ).
  • The heart tube folds into the cardiac loop, forming the basic structure and orientation of the 4 chambers of the heart (
    figure 16
    ).  Electrical activity begins.
  • Limb buds appear.
  • The respiratory diverticulum forms from the ventral aspect of the primitive foregut.
  • The pharyngeal apparatus (composed of the pharyngeal arches (
    figure 17
    ), pouches (
    figure 18
    ), grooves, and membranes), which eventually forms much of the head and neck, begins to develop.

Weeks 5-6 key events



  • The secondary brain vesicles form from the primary vesicles.
  • Neural crest cells (precursor to neural ganglia, melanocytes, and adrenal medulla) migrate from the neural folds to distal sites.
  • Bronchial buds emerge from the distal end of the respiratory diverticulum, forming the pulmonary bronchi and the beginnings of the left and right lungs.
  • The metanephros (precursor to the kidneys) begins to develop (
    figure 19
    ).
  • The midgut loop herniates through the umbilical ring to develop outside the peritoneal cavity (
    figure 20
    ).
  • The apical ectodermal ridge at the distal end of limb buds induces limb growth and differentiation.

Weeks 7-8 key events



  • Digits form through apoptosis of webbing.
  • Sexual differentiation begins (
    figure 21
    ).
  • Development of organs such as the liver, pancreas, adrenal glands, and pituitary gland occurs.
  • The gastrointestinal tract becomes patent through apoptosis.
  • The embryo is C-shaped and shows spontaneous movement.
  • Facial structures begin to emerge.

Clinical considerations



  • The embryonic stage is highly sensitive to teratogens such as alcohol, radiation, and certain medications (eg, isotretinoin, phenytoin, lithium).
  • Many major congenital malformations such as cardiac anomalies, congenital diaphragmatic hernia, renal agenesis, and neural tube defects occur as a result of defects in embryonic development.  Because organ systems develop simultaneously in close proximity to one another, interruptions in normal development may affect more than one system.  For example, abnormalities of brain development are often seen with facial anomalies, and patients with anomalies of the genital tract often have coexisting anomalies of the kidney or ureter.
  • Most pregnancies complicated by aneuploidy end in spontaneous abortion prior to reaching the fetal stage.

Fetal stage (>8 weeks after fertilization)



The fetal stage begins 8 weeks after fertilization (10 weeks gestation) and continues through birth.  This stage primarily involves the growth and maturation of organ systems.

First trimester (9-13 weeks gestational age)



  • External and internal genitalia further differentiate (
    figure 22
    ).  The mesonephric ducts degenerate in the female, and the paramesonephric ducts degenerate in the male (
    figure 23
    ).
  • Much of the endocrine system becomes functional.
  • The fetal kidneys (metanephros) begin to function.
  • The liver produces red blood cells (hematopoiesis); fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is the predominant type of hemoglobin produced.
  • The herniated midgut completes rotation and returns to the abdominal cavity (
    figure 20
    ).
  • The fetus measures approximately 3 inches in length by the end of the first trimester.

Second trimester (14-27 weeks gestation)



  • Structures such as the gut, neurons, and testes begin to migrate to their final locations as the fetus undergoes rapid growth and elongation (
    figure 25
    ).
  • The skin thickens, and lanugo (fine hair) and vernix caseosa develop.
  • Skeletal ossification continues.
  • The lung bronchiole system develops (
    figure 26
    ).
  • The fetus begins to swallow amniotic fluid, and urine production increases.
  • The auditory system becomes functional.
  • The fetus measures approximately 15 inches by the end of the second trimester.

Third trimester (28-40 weeks gestation)



  • Rapid brain development; fetal consciousness and the ability to feel pain develop by the early third trimester.  The CNS is capable of temperature regulation and maintains fetal tone and intermittent breathing movements.  The maturing autonomic nervous system leads to the reliable presence of fetal heart rate variability and accelerations (transient, abrupt increases in fetal heart rate) on electronic fetal monitoring.
  • The lungs mature as the number of alveoli rapidly increases (
    figure 26
    ).  Production of surfactant (lipoprotein that reduces surface tension and facilitates alveolar expansion) increases in the late third trimester.
  • Subcutaneous fat accumulates.
  • The bone marrow takes over as the predominant site of hematopoiesis, and adult hemoglobin (HbA) gradually replaces fetal hemoglobin.
  • The fetus usually measures 19-22 inches and weighs 6-9 lb by the end of the third trimester.

Clinical considerations



  • The fetal heartbeat becomes audible by Doppler ultrasonography around 10-12 weeks gestation, and quickening (first maternal sensation of fetal movement) occurs around 18-20 weeks.  Fetal ultrasonography is performed at 20 weeks gestation to evaluate the fetal anatomy.
  • Abnormal development during the fetal stage leads to congenital anomalies that may be more minor or more localized than those that occur due to abnormal development during the embryonic stage.  These may include:
    • Abnormalities of the female genitalia (eg, imperforate hymen, vaginal septum, uterine septum) or male genitalia (eg, undescended testis, hypospadias).
    • Abdominal wall defects (eg, omphalocele (
      figure 28
      ), gastroschisis (
      figure 29
      ))
  • Although most ossification is complete by birth, the flat bones of the skull remain separated by suture lines; the fontanelles are the soft areas where the sutures meet.  Suture lines allow molding of the skull to permit the fetus to navigate the birth canal for vaginal delivery and permit ongoing rapid brain growth in infancy.
  • Viability improves significantly after 24 weeks gestation with major improvements in survival and reduced morbidity with each additional week of gestation.  Respiratory problems are a major contributor to morbidity among preterm infants due to the relatively slow maturation of the lungs and alveoli.
  • After birth, the fetal circulation (which depends on gas exchange via the placenta rather than the lungs) transitions to the neonatal circulation due to closure of the ductus arteriosus and foramen ovale, lung expansion, and clamping of the umbilical cord (
    figure 30
    ).

Summary



Fetal development is a dynamic, finely regulated process encompassing cellular differentiation, organ formation, and functional maturation.  It begins with the preembryonic stage, which involves fertilization, mitotic divisions, and implantation into the uterine wall.  This is followed by the embryonic stage, during which the basic body plan and foundations of organs are formed.  The fetal stage is the final and longest stage and involves maturation and growth.  Appropriate progression through these stages is essential to the preparation of the fetus for extrauterine life.
